channel.title: Urban Prairies: Vacant Land in St. Louis
channel.description: Recent content on Urban Prairies: Vacant Land in St. Louis

item.title: Background
item.description: Two related demographic phenomena have helped define contemporary St. Louis: population loss and segregation. The plot above shows the significant drop in population the city has experienced since 1950, when it experienced a peak population 856,796. As of 2016, the population sat at 311,404. This 64% decline in the city’s population has left a hollowed out urban space, with streets and neighborhoods designed to accommodate hundreds of thousands more residents than currently exist in the city.

item.title: approach
item.description: The data used to develop our initial listof vacant properties was culled from a number of different sources. The first three were considered primary indicators - if one or more were true, the property was considered vacant in both the low and the high estimates. Table 1: Data Sources Indicator Source Description (1) Vacant Lot (A) Property Ownership Database Represents the City’s assessment of the property as a vacant lot.

item.title: Research Team
item.description: Principal Investigator Christopher Prener, Ph.D. is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at Saint Louis University. In addition to spearheading the Urban Praries project and its “cousin” the Streets Not Thru project, he is currently working on a book manuscript entitled Medicine at the Margins. The book examines the effect of neighborhood context and conditions on emergency medical services work, particularly with patients who have mental illnesses or substance use disorders.
